Introduction

Otitis externa (swimmer's ear) is an inflammatory condition of the external ear canal that most commonly occurs due to bacterial infection.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Several factors contribute to the development of otitis externa by disrupting the cerumen-skin barrier in the external ear canal.  Cerumen is acidic, which inhibits bacterial growth, and hydrophobic, which prevents bacterial entry and skin maceration by repelling water.  Cerumen also traps small particles that can become a nidus of infection.  Without cerumen, the moist, alkaline external ear canal would be an ideal environment for bacterial growth (

Otitis externa
).  Water exposure (eg, outdoor swimming) also introduces pathogenic bacteria into the external ear canal, leading to infection and inflammation.



Therefore, risk factors include:



  • Disruptions to the cerumen barrier:  water exposure (most common), excessive ear cleaning, occlusive devices (eg, headphones, hearing aids)
  • Disruptions to the skin barrier:  trauma (eg, cotton swabs, fingers), dermatologic conditions (eg, eczema, psoriasis)


The most common causes of bacterial otitis externa are Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which grows in water, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of otitis externa depends on symptom severity and ranges from mild to severe disease:



  • Patients with mild disease typically have mild otalgia and pruritus.  Examination usually shows only minimal erythema and edema.
  • Patients with moderate disease can have increasing otalgia and pruritus and often have erythema and edema that partially occlude the external ear canal.
  • Patients with severe disease have severe otalgia, and examination shows erythema and edema that completely occludes the external ear canal.  Fever, periauricular erythema, and lymphadenopathy may also be present.


Otalgia is typically exacerbated by manipulation of the auricle or tragus (which causes movement within the inflamed canal), even in mild cases.  Discharge or debris within the external ear canal may be thick and yellow, brown, white, or gray.  In contrast to otitis media, the tympanic membrane usually appears normal and is mobile with pneumatic insufflation.  Otitis externa can occur in adults but is more common in children and adolescents.

Diagnosis



Otitis externa is a clinical diagnosis with a thorough history, including recent water exposure, and physical examination with otoscopy.  Culture and sensitivities are usually not necessary but may be obtained in severe, recurrent, or chronic cases or in immunocompromised or postoperative patients.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for otitis externa includes:



  • Otomycosis:  In contrast to bacterial otitis externa, otomycosis causes more pruritus than pain and less edema.  Fine filaments or spores may be visible on examination.
  • Contact dermatitis:  Patients have persistent erythema and edema despite treatment for otitis externa. An allergic reaction to neomycin, a topical aminoglycoside, is a common cause.
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media with perforation:  The tympanic membrane appears inflamed, perforated, and immobile with pneumatic insufflation due to purulent fluid accumulation in the middle ear space.

Management



The first step in management of otitis externa (

figure 2
) is to remove any discharge or debris from the external ear canal, which promotes healing and allows topical medications to reach the site of infection and inflammation.  Further treatment is based on disease severity (

), as well as whether the tympanic membrane is intact; perforation is often due to prior, unrelated disease (eg, otitis media).

Mild disease with intact tympanic membrane



  • Topical acetic acid is effective in mild cases because its acidity inhibits bacterial growth.

Moderate to severe disease with intact tympanic membrane



  • Topical fluoroquinolones (eg, ciprofloxacin) are first-line treatment because they are effective against P aeruginosa and S aureus; antibiotic resistance is rare because topical medications deliver a high concentration of antibiotic directly to the infection site.  In addition, unlike systemic fluoroquinolones, topical fluoroquinolones have minimal adverse effects in adult and pediatric patients.
  • Topical aminoglycosides (eg, neomycin) are effective but ototoxic and may cause iatrogenic hearing loss if spontaneous perforation of the tympanic membrane occurs.
  • Topical glucocorticoids (eg, dexamethasone) are often added to treat inflammation in patients with severe pain or occlusive edema.

Nonintact tympanic membrane (eg, perforated, tympanostomy tube)



  • Topical fluoroquinolones are preferred because they are not acidic or ototoxic and do not damage middle ear structures.


In all cases, water exposure should be avoided until the infection has resolved.

Prognosis



A full recovery is expected with topical antibiotics.  Rare complications include periauricular cellulitis and necrotizing otitis externa as the infection spreads to surrounding soft tissue and bone at the base of the skull.  These complications occur most commonly in immunocompromised patients and present with severe otalgia that appears out of proportion to findings from the physical examination.

Prevention



Otitis externa may be prevented by wearing ear plugs while swimming and avoiding the use of cotton swabs.

Summary



Otitis externa (
